content.description:
Sit-start the undercut of the boulder, just left of No Pigs For Rent. You can start on some REALLY low holds and bump the grade up a smidgen, but then you're just mincing moves. Either way, climb through some awesome Skofield-esque ramps, then cut left. You can finish rightor directly, if you're up to itbut the grade stays the same either way. The stand-start is more like V2.

Proud line up a beautiful face. Reminiscent of the Creek Boulder at Skofield.
content.location: Just left of No Pigs For Rent.

content.description: Compression climbing up a beautiful, towering, and richly featured bulge. Sit start very low. Right hand grabs a vertical edge, left hand grabs a cool ramp/edge. First move is a left-hand throw up to a sloper. Pretty hard. Next, huck up and right to an edge (crux). The rest is a mental battle of tricky feet and nerves. Incredible!
content.protection: Two pads are nice. Three are better. You can fall off the top, and it's a long way down.

content.description: Stand start with your right hand on a pretty okay side-pull, left just around the arete to a small crimp and go up from there. Keeping it at that so I don't short you of any fun problem solving :)
content.protection: A pad or two. The PO is clear right now, but inevitably is growing back.
content.location: This is a new boulder addition to Hat Creek Cattle Company named the Deebs Boulder. Same approach up the creek to HCCC, however when you come out of the creek you should notice a trail I put in (really just path clear of PO). The path forks; left brings you to the original boulders, right brings you to Deebs. Newt V4 is on the backside of Deebs.

content.description: Quality lowball with some excellent holds. Begin with both hands on huge hueco. Top out directly via a possible beached-whale maneuver (unless you figure out your feet).
content.protection: Super flat, soft landing. Barely needs one pad.
content.location: On the backside of the large boulder facing No Pigs For Rent.

content.description: Sit start. Slap up the openhanded edges, figure out your feet, and make a long reach. Beautiful stone.
Really just a slightly harder version of Blue Duck. Same start as Blue Duck, but head immediately up and left towards the beautiful sloping edge. Slappy-slap, then press it out.
content.location: Same start as Blue Duck, on the big low hueco.
